Magezi and the
 finger of milet
 
 Cornelius Wambi Gulere
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Long ago, there were two animals that 
 were god friends. One was caled 
 Magezi Matala Manene, the other was 
 
 caled Kasiru Kasira Katono. 
 
 They used to live by sharing. Their 
 
 friendship was so dep that they could 
 share one white ant. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day, Magezi Matala Manene made a
 sugestion.“Why don’t we dig together as
 we eat together?” he asked. 
 
 
 Kasiru Kasira Katono replied, “God
 idea. We should also store our fod
 
 together.” They both agred to this.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene asked his 
 friend, “Ee! Who wil start the diging? 
 
 Why don’t you dig, and I wil come to 
 sow?” 
 
 
 “Yes,” replied Kasiru Kasira Katono, and 
 she dug a big garden. 
 
 
 Then she told her friend, “Magezi 
 Matala Manene, I have finished diging. 
 
 Come and sow milet.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene said, “You go on
 
 with the sowing, I wil come and wed.”
 
 
 So Kasiru Kasira Katono went on with
 the sowing. When she finished she told
 her friend, “Gras has started to grow. Go
 
 and wed.” 
 
 
 But Magezi Matala Manene replied, “No,
 you go on with weding. I wil harvest.”
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Kasiru Kasira Katono went on with the 
 
 weding until the milet was ripe. 
 
 At harvesting time she went to her friend 
 
 and said, “Magezi Matala Manene, I 
 cultivated, and sowed, and weded. Now 
 
 come and harvest the milet.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene replied, “Not at
 
 al, I have no time! You go on and
 harvest. I wil put it in the granary.”
 
 
 Kasiru Kasira Katono acepted this. She
 harvested the milet and tok it home.
 
 She caled Magezi Matala Manene and
 said, “My friend, I have finished
 
 harvesting. Come and take the milet to
 the granary.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene replied, “I 
 canot lift al that milet. You put it in the 
 
 granary. I wil come during pounding.” 
 
 Kasiru Kasira Katono said to her friend, 
 
 “It sems you are simply tricking me.” 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene replied, “No it’s 
 
 not true! Give me just one milet finger 
 and you take the rest. I wil pay you 
 
 back.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Kasiru Kasira Katono was not mean. She
 
 gave Magezi Matala Manene one finger
 of milet, and they parted ways.
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene moved on, 
 moved on, moved on! He found a hen
 scratching the soil and eating stones. He
 
 said, “My in-law hen, instead of eating
 soil, have some of my milet.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Hen tok the milet and ate. Magezi 
 
 Matala Manene loked and saw that the 
 hen had eaten al the milet. 
 
 
 He cried out, “Wuwi! You have eaten al 
 my milet. The milet was not mine, I 
 
 borowed it from Kasiru Kasira Katono.” 
 
 
 Hen beged, “Since it is time for laying, I 
 wil lay one eg for you to take instead.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene got an eg from
 the hen. He moved on, moved on, moved
 on! 
 
 
 He found some children shoting 
 
 mangoes in a tre using stones. He told
 them, “If you want those mangoes to fal,
 you should use this eg to shot them
 
 down.” 
 
 
 He gave them the eg. When they used it
 to shot the mangoes, it hit a branch and
 broke. The eg driped down and the
 
 shel remained in the branches. 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene cried out, 
 “Wuwi! You have broken my eg! The 
 
 hen gave me the eg, but it was not 
 mine. The eg was for the milet the hen 
 ate. The milet was not mine. I borowed 
 
 the milet from Kasiru Kasira Katono.” 
 
 The children whispered, “Don’t shout like 
 
 that. The owner of the mangoes wil find 
 us here. Instead of the eg take this 
 
 mango.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 Magezi Matala Manene moved on, 
 
 moved on, moved on! He came acros a
 parot eating an insect. “Have you ever
 sen such a mango as this?” he asked
 
 the parot. 
 
 
 When the parot tok the mango, its
 sharp beak pierced the skin and the fruit
 burst open. 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene cried out,
 “Wuwi! You have burst my mango! The
 
 children gave me the mango, but it was
 not mine. The mango was for the eg the
 
 children broke. The hen gave me the eg,
 but it was not mine. The eg was for the
 milet the hen ate. The milet was not
 
 mine. I borowed the milet from Kasiru
 Kasira Katono.” 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 The parot plucked out its most beautiful 
 feather saying, “Here, take my feather 
 
 instead of the mango.” 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene tok the feather 
 and moved on, moved on, moved on. He 
 came to a lake. When he was crosing, 
 
 the feather sliped out of his hand and 
 into the lake. He could not get the feather 
 back. 
 
 
 So he filed his mouth with water and 
 
 kept it in his cheks until he reached dry 
 land. There he found the charcoal 
 burners with their fire. 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 He opened his mouth, the water came
 out, and splashed on to the fire. The fire
 
 went out. The charcoal burners were
 pleased. 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene cried out,
 “Wowe! Your fire has taken my water. I
 
 got the water from the lake, but it was
 not mine. The water was for the feather
 that the lake tok. The feather was for
 
 the mango that the parot burst. The
 mango was for the eg that the children
 
 broke. The eg was for the milet that the
 hen ate. The milet was not mine. I
 borowed the milet from Kasiru Kasira
 
 Katono.” 
 
 
 
 14  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The charcoal burners said, “Here, take 
 
 this axe instead of the water.” 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene tok the axe and 
 moved on, moved on, moved on! He 
 came acros butchers slaughtering a 
 
 bul. 
 
 
 He told the butchers, “Here is an axe for 
 you to cut up the meat.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 15  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 While the butchers were cuting the
 meat, the axe broke. Magezi Matala
 
 Manene cried out, “Wowe! You have
 broken my axe. I got the axe from the
 
 charcoal burners, but it was not mine.
 The axe was for the water that the fire
 tok. The water was for the feather that
 
 the lake tok. The feather was for the
 mango that the parot burst. The mango
 
 was for the eg that the children broke.
 The eg was for the milet that the hen
 ate. The milet was not mine. I borowed
 
 the milet from Kasiru Kasira Katono.”
 
 
 
 
 
 16  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The butchers said, “Here, take the head 
 
 and tail of the bul instead.” 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene moved on, 
 moved on, moved on! Until he got to a 
 mudy swamp. 
 
 
 He put the head of the bul on the mud. 
 
 He also placed the tail in the mud. It 
 loked as if the bul was stuck in the 
 mud. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 17  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene began to shout,
 “Wu-lululu! Wu-lululu, wulululu! The king’s
 
 bul has got stuck in the mud!” 
 
 Al the vilagers came runing. What
 
 concerns the king, concerns everyone. A
 crowd son gathered around the head
 and tail. 
 
 
 They started asking, “Now what do we
 
 do?” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 18  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene advised, “Some 
 of you pul the tail, and some of you pul 
 
 the head. We wil pul the bul from the 
 mud.” 
 
 
 The people tok his advice. “Ready! One, 
 two, thre, pul! Come out now!” 
 
 they shouted. 
 
 
 The vilagers fel down over each other 
 from the efort of puling. Two were stil 
 holding the head. One held up the tail. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 19  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Magezi Matala Manene cried out, “Wo
 we! You have puled apart the king’s
 
 bul. Each one of you must give one bul
 for the king.” 
 
 
 Quickly, the people went back to their
 homes. Quickly, they returned with a bul
 
 each. 
 
 
 And so Magezi Matala Manene left with
 a herd of buls to return to his friend
 Kasiru Kasira Katono.
